Hey man, I found your thread through google and I just wanted to chime in with my personal experience.

So first of all, I HATE rubber tip headphones. They sound like crap, they sound like my head is inside a box, I feel claustrophobic, and to top it all off, they never stay in my ears and they hurt after a couple hours of use. I’ve tried TONS of them, I had beats IEMs when I was young and dumb, I had sennheiser IEMs (by far the most comfortable ones out of the bunch, but still a pain), I’ve even had god damn Apple IEMs (bet ya you didn’t know about these)

So having set the stage, my friend lent me their Airpods pro for a day to try out. They were the most comfortable and plush fit I’ve ever worn. The sound stage felt open, and the transparency mode sounded acceptable (which is leagues above any other transparency mode I’ve tried yet), and I literally forgot I had them on after just 5 minutes of wearing them.

So my point is, don’t make the wrong decision based on the potential discomfort or fit issues of rubber tips, you might be very surprised.

That said, I’m personally leaning towards the new ones, because of the better lost mode tracking and better microphones (I use them heavily for long phone calls, so mic quality is very important to me)

I think you should try them both out and figure it out for yourself. Remember Apple has a pretty good return policy.

Late to the party here so I’m not sure if you made your purchase or not yet, but there are two main factors to consider about your purchase: Ear feel and ANC (active noise-cancelling). The actual monitors themselves are identical, so the base sound quality is the same between both pairs.

Gen 3 pods are classic earbud in style, with no in-ear tips. Pros are your in-ear rubber-feel tips. Some people swear by each style respectively. Personally I find that while sound quality feels a bit better with in-ear tips, the earplug-feel of them makes me feel almost claustrophobic and it gets uncomfortable very fast. You also have to clean the tips regularly and replace them after a certain amount of time. On the other hand, they will offer a tailored fit to your ear and will enclose your audio experience and help further block outside noise. It comes down to personal preference on this matter.

Next up is ANC, active noise-cancelling. This is where your AirPods will emit a range of frequencies that block outside noise and allows a more ‘soundproof’ style of listening. Personally, I can’t stand ANC - the frequencies played very obviously interfere with the quality of your audio output (this is more noticeable for people with a ‘trained ear’ such as musicians or studio technicians.). However some people very much prefer ANC as it blocks all outside noise. One benefit is that if you are listening to music or talking on the phone in a noisy environment it will help considerably.

For me, because I prefer non-rubber-tips and I can’t stand ANC; the gen 3s we’re the obvious choice.
